Message.Msg: I'm highly suspicious of your interest in the details of my military service. At the risk of undermining that admiration, I will admit to a 4-year hitch as enlisted swine in the USAF, Vietnam era, F-4 Phantom flight line radar weapons systems technician. I supported combat operations of the 432nd Tactical Fighter Wing, including the Linebacker I and II air offensives (tactical bombing of the Ho Chi Minh trail and MIG-CAP for the B-52 strategic bombing of Hanoi) from Udorn RTAFB in northern Thailand. I made sergeant in 20 months, and took a 5 1/2 month early (honorable) discharge in Udorn Thailand to work for another 2 years as a Defense Communications Agency contract tech controller. If you want to get a feel for the conditions under which I served, I suggest reading "Fast Company: Jet Pilots and the Vietnam Experience" by John Darrell Sherwood. ROTFLMAO don't be awed; I certainly wasn't. I'm sure your service was far more heroic than mine.

Message.Title: RECESSION/DEPRESSION DATA OUT
Message.Msg: This morning’s data was bad – worse than recent poor macro data; however, the market got yet another “stick save.” Thursday morning’s economic news was, in a word: RECESSIONARY. Durable Goods data was stinky…New orders for manufactured durable goods in August decreased $30.1 billion or 13.2 percent to $198.5 billion, the U.S. Census Bureau announced today. This decrease, down following three consecutive monthly increases, was the largest decrease since January 2009 and followed a 3.3 percent July increase. Excluding transportation, new orders decreased 1.6 percent. Excluding defense, new orders decreased 12.4 percent. Transportation equipment, down following four consecutive monthly increases, had the largest decrease, $27.8 billion or 34.9 percent to $51.9 billion. Who needs durable goods data when surely other economic strength was able to pull GDP much higher than expected? After all, this is a recovery – right? Uh, not so much. In fact, GDP and Durable Goods data were both so bad it made Art Cashin exclaim on TV that they were recessionary…and he’s correct. ZeroHedge said the following about the all-important GDP data that has somehow become meaningless… So much for the US recovery (we will never tire of saying that). After the first Q2 GDP revision bubbled up from 1.5% to 1.7%, the sell-side brigade was confident that the rate of growth would continue and final Q2 GDP would be in line. Instead, we got an absolute shock of a print, with the final Q2 GDP print coming in at a ridiculously low 1.25% (rounded up to 1.3%), below the lowest Wall Street estimate of 1.4%, and the lowest number since the revised 0.1% reported in January 2011. Here is the final GDP trendline: Q4 2011: 4.1%; Q1 2012: 2.0%; Q2 2012: 1.25%. Luckily, at least "housing has bottomed." The reason for the major contraction in the final print: a downward revision to all favorable components except Government which detracted the least from growth in years at just -0.14%. Of note - Personal Consumption was 1.06%, down from the 1.20% per the second revision. If nothing, we now know just what data Bernanke was looking at on an advance basis to come up with QEternity, and we also know the reason for the media and administration's all in gamble to reflate housing yet again. If the housing market does not go up courtesy of infinite cheap leverage, it could be curtains for the Bernanke reflation experiment. Thank goodness, he centrally-planned policy vehicle once upon a time known as "the market" refuses to react to this horrendous, if only for the meaningless economy, news.

Message.Title: OPEC Says Supply Ample, Speculation Driving Price
Message.Msg: OPEC Says Supply Ample, Speculation Driving Price , | 27 September 2012 | 06:18 AM ET Oil supply will be more than sufficient to meet demand this year and beyond, OPEC's Secretary General said on Thursday, but added the price of fuel is being driven higher by speculation. "There has been no shortage of oil in the market. Producers have been able to meet consumer needs," Abdullah al-Badri told an energy conference. "We also see this as being the case for the rest of 2012 and the foreseeable future." Oil prices surged in March to $128 a barrel, the highest level since 2008, because of concern about possible supply shortages. Prices have since fallen back and brent crude was trading around $118 on Thursday. "Today the price continues to be driven by excessive speculation," Badri said. OPEC at a meeting in December set a target to produce 30 million barrels per day, settling an argument which broke out in 2011 after Iran and other members opposed a Saudi-led plan to raise OPEC's production ceiling. Output has remained above the target all year as Libyan supply recovered after being virtually shut down during the 2011 uprising against Muammar Gaddafi's rule. The extra oil is filling gaps caused by an unusually large number of supply outages globally, which have also helped support prices. Supply breaks were running at nearly 1.3 million bpd as of early April. The additional supply has also offset a decline in exports from Iran, which is facing stiffening western sanctions over its disputed nuclear energy program. Iranian oil exports were running at between 200,000 and 300,000 barrels per day below last year's level, Maria van der Hoeven, head of the International Energy Agency, told Thursday's conference. Iranian officials have said the country exported an average of 2.2 million barrels a day last year. July supply from the 12-member Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries ran at 31.75 million barrels per day (bpd), the high est since September 2008, which was shortly before it agreed to a series of supply curbs to combat recession and collapsing demand, based on Reuters surveys

Topic.Title: I just heard a story

Message.Msg: Stories like this are geared to emotion. The rule of law is designed to counter that. BAC doesn't own the loan in all likelihood, but only services it, if the bank is even involved. An investor owns the loan and all the terms & conditions of it, including whether it is assumable. Death does not transfer ownership of debt, only of the asset. If the asset is encumbered, as this one sounds like it was, and the instrument of debt was not assumable (as it sounds like this one was not), then the encumberance must be satisfied -- either paid off or refinanced. If he couldn't qualify for the loan and there weren't enough assets in dad's estate to pay it off, then so sorry to say, it is simply a matter of rule of law. Throw whatever derogatory language you will; the Dodd/Frank regulatory environment makes it very difficult for banks to make loans to people who cannot afford them, just as Messrs. Dodd & Frank originally made it mandatory for banks to give loans to people who could never repay them, which caused the subprime meltdown. And the investor could sue the bank for not fulfilling its obligation under the mortgage t's & c's. This particular hero to our nation has to make a decision that is no more or less relevant to any American, whether war hero or protesting hippie. That decision is whether he can afford to keep an asset he inherited. If he can raise money from friends or find an alternate financier, then all parties are served. But pushing this as a feel-bad story with the only culpability being with the bank is a huge deviation of aim and object. Time to course correct - No blame to the bank for doing what it is legally obligated to do. No blame to the soldier in his father's death or inheriting the house through no fault of his own. Just a need to do this guy a favor and find an alternative that keeps the bank on the right side of the law (which it sounds like it is now), and keeps the soldier in his inherited home -- and do so without impacting the bank's shareholders, who are under no obligation to allow the bank to purposely lose money by picking winners and losers outside of the law.
